thread.title: Court documents reveal baby buried in family's backyard was a gi
thread.title_full: Court documents reveal baby buried in family's backyard was a gi - KPTV - FOX 12

author: Lee Peck, FOX10 News Reporter
title: Court documents reveal baby buried in family's backyard was a gi
text:
MOBILE, AL (WALA) - Court documents are shedding more light on the case involving a Mobile woman accused of burying her newborn baby in the family's backyard. Authorities charged Ashley Wilkins, with abuse of a corpse last Thursday.
Police received a 911 call the week before to 3722 Swansea Drive and discovered the infant's remains buried in the backyard.
Court documents released Monday said they believe the death happened inside the home and that Wilkins suspected of using drugs at the time of the baby's death.
"On Thursday October 8, 2015, at approximately 1149 hours, police officers with the Mobile Police Department Fourth Precinct responded to Swansea 3722 Drive in reference to locating a partially buried infant in the backyard of the location. Upon arrival, officers located an infant in the backyard. the infant was deceased inside a grocery bag, partially buried with dirt. It was further reported that the infant was the result of a miscarriage that occurred over the weekend at the residence.."
According to the documents, investigators also search included any and all vehicles and storage facilities on the property. Several items were seized as evidence in the case, including a pair of panties, several towels and wash cloths, and blood swab from the bathroom.
Wilkins Representation
Meanwhile, Wilkins attorney Jeff Deen says the public should hold judgment until all the facts of the case are revealed.
“I think as this thing develops will see that it is not as atrocious and horrible as people are going to think it is,” Deen said.
According to Deen, a family member of Wilkins' dialed 911 and alerted police.
Furthermore, on the day investigators searched the home Mobile police reported a woman had a miscarriage and no foul play was expected.
“It's a tragedy for her family, it's is a tragedy for her and we just need to hash it all out and see if it's even a criminal act,” Deen said.
Wilkins is set to appear in court on October 29, 2015.
See court documents here:
FOX10 News will continue to follow this story and bring you updates on this case.
